Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chem-STEM Scholars Program is recruiting 41 academically talented and financially needy students into chemistry and biochemistry over the five years of the project. Students share a common curriculum involving degree tracks meeting American Chemical Society (ACS) guidelines for a professional undergraduate education. Based on historical matriculation patterns at the university, both freshmen and sophomore entry points are being used to recruit students. Entering 2012-2016 freshmen cohorts have $5,000 scholarships available; all scholars remaining in good standing are supported for four years. 2012-2015 sophomore cohorts, comprised primarily of students from other majors or transfers, have $5,000 scholarships available; all sophomore scholars maintaining satisfactory progress are supported for three years. At the end of the project, the university is sustaining Chem-STEM scholarships for NSF-funded cohorts who have not yet graduated.

Intellectual Merit: The project is developing the best practices to recruit, engage, and retain students taking rigorous undergraduate programs. Program goals are to:
1) provide increased professional educational opportunities in chemistry for academically talented and financially needy students through sustainable recruitment and scholarship programs;
2) increase student retention to degree completion;
3) improve support services through targeted academic monitoring, community building, seminars, internships, and mentoring; and
4) matriculate 85% of scholarship students into teaching, graduate programs, or industrial scientific positions.

Broader Impacts include: 1) student completion of academic programs involving research and internships; 2) participation of students from underrepresented groups; 3) increased involvement of industry in providing science internships; 4) dissemination of research activities to high schools; and 5) availability of Chem-STEM graduates to the state workforce. Findings achieved by students during research projects are being disseminated through presentations and publications.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
On April 11, 2012, Winthrop University’s Chemistry Program was competitively selected for a $598,500 National Science Foundation Grant for the sole purpose of awarding scholarships to chemistry and biochemistry students at Winthrop with academic potential and financial need. This was a five-year grant with a start date of July 1, 2012 and an end date of June 30, 2017.

Recruitment: A major goal was to provide increased professional and educational opportunities in chemistry for 41 majors. This goal was surpassed with the recruitment of 62 academically talented and financially needy students into the program over the five years of the project.  Winthrop Chemistry S-STEM scholars with unmet financial need received annual $5,000 scholarships.  All Chemistry S-STEM Scholars shared a common curriculum involving degree tracks meeting American Chemical Society (ACS) guidelines for a professional undergraduate education. Based on historical matriculation patterns at the university, both freshmen and sophomore entry points were used to recruit students into nine separate groups that included five entering freshman cohorts during the 2012-2016 period and four returning student sophomore cohorts during 2012-2015. At the end of the grant period, five of the nine cohorts had graduated. Winthrop is sustaining Chemistry S-STEM by awarding $5,000 annual scholarships to scholars in the four remaining S-STEM cohorts graduating during the 2017-2020 post-award period.

Retention: To established a community of strong support and intellectual engagement in chemistry; entering S-STEM scholars participated in dedicated lower-division Chemistry S-STEM seminar courses and underwent intensive academic performance monitoring during their freshman and sophomore years. Upper-class scholars took dedicated upper-division Chemistry S-STEM professional development seminar courses focused on preparation for graduate or industrial opportunities. Upper-class scholars were expected to purse research.

At the end of the grant period, 28 Chemistry S-STEM scholars had graduated and another 24 were in good standing. The overall program retention rate was 84%. This is much higher than the grant''s 55% retention goal and the 31% retention rate prior to the grant. The 16% (10) of scholars leaving the program all either changed majors or transferred to other schools; half were retained at Winthrop; they completed or are still pursuing Winthrop degrees in fields that include biology, human nutrition, computer science, and psychology. The overall Winthrop retention rate was 92%.

Student Research:  Heavy emphasis was placed on Chemistry S-STEM scholar research engagement through courses, Winthrop summer research experience, or competitive summer external research fellowships. Twenty-seven of the 28 Chemistry S-STEM scholars who had graduated by the end of the grant were engaged in substantive research experiences (the one exception was a student in the National Guard with substantive summer military commitments). During the five years of the grant, 21 Chemistry S-STEM scholars were competitively awarded external summer research fellowships at Notre Dame, Clemson, Brookhaven National Lab, St Jude Children’s Research Hospital, Rutgers, Wake Forest University, Northeastern University, Medical University of South Carolina, Tennessee, and other locations. Another 38 Chemistry S-STEM Scholars were awarded Winthrop Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE) 8-10 week research fellowships. Fourteen Chemistry S-STEM Scholars completed a two-semester research course that included the oversight of a separate faculty committee.

Student Outcomes:  At the end of the grant period, 28 Chemistry S-STEM scholars had earned a BS in Chemistry and 26 (93%) are known to have been successfully placed into graduate school, industry, or government scientific positions, far exceeding the grant’s 85% goal.  The two remaining placements involve an alum who is now a military spouse stationed at a very remote location and a second alum who was interviewing for positions in the biotechnology industry at the time of last contact in 2016. Outcomes for the other 26 scholars are outlined below:

Thirteen Winthrop Chemistry S-STEM alumni entered graduate programs:

  • Six into PhD chemistry programs at Alabama, Duke, Johns Hopkins, Virginia Tech, UCLA, and Clemson.
  • Three into Professional Health doctoral programs: Pharmacy School at East Tennessee State, Medical School at USC School of Medicine in Greenville; and Pharmacy School at the Medical University of South Carolina.
  • Four into Masters’ Degree programs: Business Analytics at the University of Virginia, The School of Marine Science at the University of Delaware, Forensic Science at Marshall University, and Forensic Science at Townson University.

Thirteen Chemistry S-STEM alumni accepted scientific positions in government or industry:

  • Laboratory Technician with TE Connectivity (Connector & Sensor Manufacturer)
  • Quality Control Chemist at InChem Corp (Phenoxy Resins)
  • Quality Control Chemist with ACTEGA WIT (Specialty Coatings)
  • Scientist position with MARS Research and Development (Pet Food Products)
  • Forensic Chemist position with the Columbia, SC Police Department
  • Research Assistant position at Pavco Inc. (Electroplating)
  • Pharmacy Technician position
  • Chemist position with G&W Laboratories (Pharmaceuticals)
  • Manufacturing Chemist at High Purity Standards
  • Chemist with AkzoNobel Inc.
  • Deputy Coroner position with the Lexington, SC Coroner’s Office
  • Technical Service Specialist position with Pavco Inc. (Electroplating)
  • Scientist position with Pantheon Inc. (Pharmaceuticals)

Last Modified: 09/25/2017
Modified by: Patrick M Owens
